Literature Review: Indole-3-carbinol (I3C) is a naturally occurring compound found in cruciferous vegetables such as broccoli, Brussels sprouts, cabbage, and kale. Its formation is a result of the enzymatic hydrolysis of glucobrassicin, a glucosinolate present in these vegetables, upon damage to the plant tissue, such as during chopping or chewing. I3C has garnered significant attention in the scientific community due to its potential health benefits and its role in the prevention and treatment of various chronic diseases. Upon ingestion, I3C undergoes acid condensation in the stomach to form several derivatives, among which 3,3′-diindolylmethane (DIM) is the most studied and biologically active. Both I3C and DIM have been shown to modulate multiple signaling pathways and molecules that regulate critical cellular processes, including oxidation, inflammation, proliferation, differentiation, apoptosis, angiogenesis, and immunity. This literature review aims to provide an overview of the occurrence of I3C in nature and foods, its health-beneficial properties, and the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying its effects. The health benefits of I3C and DIM have been extensively studied in both in vitro and in vivo models. These compounds have demonstrated potent anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, anti-obesity, anti-diabetic, cardioprotective, anti-cancer, anti-hypertensive, neuroprotective, and bone-protective effects. The anti-cancer properties of I3C and DIM are particularly noteworthy, with studies showing their ability to inhibit the proliferation of cancer cells, induce apoptosis, and suppress tumor growth in various cancer models, including breast, prostate, and colon cancer. These effects are mediated through the modulation of key signaling pathways such as the NF-κB, PI3K/AKT, and MAPK pathways, as well as the regulation of cell cycle proteins and apoptosis-related molecules. In addition to their anti-cancer effects, I3C and DIM have been shown to exert protective effects against cardiovascular diseases by improving lipid profiles, reducing oxidative stress, and inhibiting the formation of atherosclerotic plaques. Their anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties also contribute to their protective effects against neurodegenerative diseases and osteoporosis. The mechanisms underlying these effects include the inhibition of pro-inflammatory cytokines, the activation of antioxidant enzymes, and the modulation of bone remodeling processes. Despite the promising health benefits of I3C and DIM, further research is needed to fully elucidate their mechanisms of action and to evaluate their efficacy and safety in human clinical trials. The current body of evidence, primarily derived from preclinical studies, highlights the potential of I3C and DIM as therapeutic agents for the prevention and treatment of chronic diseases. However, challenges remain in translating these findings into clinical practice, including the need for standardized dosing regimens, the identification of biomarkers for monitoring therapeutic responses, and the assessment of potential side effects and interactions with other medications. In conclusion, I3C and DIM represent promising bioactive compounds with significant potential for the prevention and treatment of chronic diseases. Their ability to modulate multiple cellular and molecular pathways underscores their versatility as therapeutic agents. Future research should focus on addressing the gaps in our understanding of their mechanisms of action and on conducting well-designed clinical trials to evaluate their efficacy and safety in humans.
